well ... the shadow is almost under the bodies so ... I'd say the time here is noon...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
Is the tram horse drawn or is it just running someone over? I don't see any wires but there's a couple of legs up the front.

edit: "Discussions towards electrification began in late 1890", so it's definitely a horse.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: I assume it's at the top of Grafton Street. There wouldn't be any business for the sidecars at any other corner of the green.

comment.author: 93076316@N00
comment._content:
None of the park's corners has a rounded fence today. Also the cobbled surface and the tramways have long been gone.
Ironically, there are as many carts and horses in the picture as there are nowadays. Some things never change :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] Yep, with Grafton Street over the photographer's left shoulder, looking down towards the Shelbourne Hotel and Merrion Row beyond...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Fusiliers Arch which dominates this corner now was not built until 1907.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The trams mean after 1872 at the earliest.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is a tantalising billboard at the bottom right, just out of shot!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I know! Love our photographers, but if I could travel back in time, I'd be beating them with their own tripods for every out-of-focus or sliver of poster that they tease us with...

Erring on the side of 1873 as earliest, thank you, which brings us to a 10 year window: 1873-83...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Since this photo was taken, there have been substantial renovations carried out on the former Hibernian United Service Club building – the building with the flags – including the addition of a bay window to the lower storeys.  The Dictionary of Irish Architects lists two entries for this building – 1848: Plans for steps; and 1878: Alterations.  Unfortunately it does not say what those ‘alterations’ were – we would have to refer to the drawings in the McCurdy & Mitchell Collection of the Irish Architecture Archive.  If we knew for sure what those alterations were then that might date this photo to before 1878.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Still trying to work out Irish C19th road rules ...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is an interesting picture. In it we see horse drawn trams, so not a million years from ours, but the club [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] references has its bay window, and there is a stone pillar at the corner of Stephen's Green itself. I think the pillar suggests the work done to open the Green to the public (in 1880), and it should be in our shot if built, so ours is before 1880. The fact that the bay window is in that one suggests that it was included in the 1878 alterations, and that our shot is earlier.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Before 1880, there was no gate at this corner, from 1880 to 1907, there was a gate that looked like the one at the SE corner today.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] So, now we're down to 1873-1880...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'm confident it is 1878 or earlier, based on the bay window.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Agree before September 1880 as there is no Drinking Fountain, for people, horses, sheep nor dogs. 

A much more elaborate drinking fountain was erected immediately outside the north side of the Green in September of 1880 which should be understood in the context of the recently opened park. It was constructed to face down Dawson’s Street and consists of an ornamental pillar of grey Cornish granite, twenty feet high, and surmounted by an Irish high cross. Water flowed from spouts on four sides into a circular basin (approached by two steps) where there were four drinking cups. There were also a second level of troughs on each side for horses and a third tier for dogs and sheep. An inscription recorded the fountain as the gift of Lady Laura Grattan to the Corporation and citizens. It was erected by the Metropolitan Drinking Fountain and Cattle Trough Association of London. 66
The trough on the north side of it has been moved further away to accommodate traffic lights.

comment.author: 71822085@N03
comment._content:
Hi!
Using a combination of Photoshop Level Adjustments, squinting at the shop signs and Thom's Street Directory from 1877, I'm certain that the names of the shops are, from the very edge of the shot:

No. 4 Booth & Son Watch and Clockmakers & Mfrs of Turret Clocks &C 
No. 5 Mrs. Cantley, Baby Linen Warehouse
No. 6 Thomas Drew Architect
No. 7 Robert Smyth & Sons, Grocers and Wine Merchants 

If you play around with the contrast you can definitely make out Smyth & Sons on No. 7.

Great shot by the way!

Dave

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/71822085@N03] Thanks for that technical and squinting work! Means I could add a great brace of tags to this one.
